author: antoine
title: Cardano Hub Caracas
description: Caracas n'a pas de communauté Cardano visible. Le Venezuela souffre de la pire inflation du monde. Les gens ne savent pas que Cardano est une option

f6_assessments.q0: In an effort to address the fact that Venezuela has the highest level of inflation in the world and that there is no Cardano community in Venezuela, the team intends to host a series of educational events in Spanish led by members of the community. Additionally, it provides a number of objectives that I consider appropriate and aligned with the objectives of this challenge. The impact of the campaign was evaluated through success metrics, where one of them is described as "Create XX new Cardano users per event" while I agree with this, it would have been interesting to learn what is meant by new users. This is because one of the items requested in the budget is airdrops, which would cause that metric to no longer have the desired success.
f6_assessments.q1: The proponent asserts that he has extensive experience organizing Blockchain events. However, no references are provided to support his claim. Regarding the budget, it is broken down into three subcategories. They are, however, insufficient for an accurate assessment of the requested amount. As an example, $10000 was requested for "Salary for local event organizers and workshop presenters", nevertheless, to assess this item accurately, it is necessary to determine how many persons will be hired to coordinate the event, and how many will be hired to conduct the workshops.An aspect of the budget that concerns me is the allocation of $10,000 for ADA airdrops. Considering that, on the one hand, it is likely to attract the attention of some people who perceive it as free money, on the other hand, I believe that the kind of people who are attracted by this kind of marketing strategy do not necessarily relate to Cardano or Catalyst.
f6_assessments.q2: On the auditability aspect, the author of the proposal does a good job. A roadmap is presented for 3, 6 and 12 months each with a brief description of what is expected to happen at each point in time. As it is a simple proposal, I think it can be easy to audit. However, as I mentioned in the impact section, I think more effort needs to be put into defining the impact metrics so that there is better alignment with the challenge of the proposal.
f6_assessments.reply:
Thanks for your review. To address your concerns:

- Impact metrics is something we are continuously working on. We see your point about holders not being the best metric for new users, though undoubtedly it brings new people into the ecosystem. 

- We propose measuring new Cardano users as the number of people who stake ADA, and who vote on Cardano Catalyst

- My name is Antoine and I have been organizing this meetup in Toronto since 2017 https://www.meetup.com/Blockchain-Developers-Canada/
And this one since 2014 https://www.meetup.com/The-Bitcoin-Bay/

- By posting our own feedback, we would like to address the most pressing concerns about this proposal, acknowledging that the lack of details related to team member identification could lead to misunderstandings. As it stands currently, the team working on this project consists of four individuals with different profesional backgrounds (which include extensive experience hosting both crypto and non crypto events), but will be expanded to ten in the immediate future:

• Antoine De Vuyst (Canada) 
• Milangeli Romero (Venezuela)
• José Ramírez (Venezuela)
• Diana Aguilar (Venezuela)

Once our team grows with the purpose of undertaking the initiative of our proposal in the most efficient way, it will be formed by: 

— Community management: Two team members.
— Online and in-person workshop presenters: Three team members.
— Event organizers: Four team members.
— Social media management: One team member.

- We will be reframing airdrops as community rewards, which should incentivize community contribution draw more people who are passionate about Cardano!

f6_assessments.q0:
The project seems to be a copy/paste proposal from the previous Fund with the same goals but for a different country. Using the same path to succes with the same team and for an audience that speaks the very same language as in Argentina the proposal has a good chance to be implemented.

The proposals fits into the challenge objectives, based on the presented info.
f6_assessments.q1:
According to the info on the meetup channel the team behind this project has the necessary skills and experience to carry on this project. It is recommended, for better visibility of the team members, to provide some direct links to some completed workshops.

The budget is outlined and broken down into identifiable items. However, compared with the requested amount to implement the same project in Argentina seems that the budget is overestimated. Buenos Aires has a population 7 times bigger than what is in Caracas but the funds requested for the Caracas hub are couple of times greater than the fund requested for Buenos Aires. It is unclear what is the rationale behind this estimation.

A timetable with achievable milestone is presented but the proposer has not considered any challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation. (what drives people in Caracas to onboard the Cardano ecosystem?
f6_assessments.q2:
There are some KPIs/metrics define to measure the success of the proposal and look the same as in the Buenos Aires project. Clarifying why for a 7 times smaller population can produce the same output will give e better chance for the project to be funded. What works for a chosen populated area doesn't mean that it will work for any populated area, no matter its side.

The proposal makes it clear for an outsider what is the direction of this proposal and what is to be done and how.
f6_assessments.reply:
Thank you for your review. To address your comments: 

- One of our team members, Antoine, has  been organizing this meetup in Toronto for 7 years: https://www.meetup.com/The-Bitcoin-Bay/

- We also have 3 Venezuelan members on the Cardano Hub Caracas team with additional event organizing experience (non crypto)

• Milangeli Romero (Venezuela)
• Antoine De Vuyst (Canada) 
• José Ramírez (Venezuela)
• Diana Aguilar (Venezuela)

You can come talk to us in our telegram group! t.me/Cardano_Caracas

- We would like to add that although the Buenos Aires and Caracas proposals might seem very similar from an outside perspective, their respective approach, focus, dynamics and expectations are very different, which will in turn allow us to present individual results. It's not so much about the population size of the two, but the massive potential for adoption in a country with the world's worst inflation. With these funds we can go a lot further in Caracas than in Buenos Aires!

f6_assessments.q0: The issue being Caracas has no visible ADA community While Venezuela is suffering from high inflation and people lack the knowledge of Cardano as an option. The proposer is trying to address this issue by creating a Cardano community hub in Caracas and wants to conduct a workshop in Spanish to increase awareness about Cardano. Therefore this proposal effectively addresses the issue
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer has required experience as he had been hosting bitcoin meetups and workshops since 2013 and Hosting Cardano meetups. These experiences should be enough to make the proposal a reality.
The proposal consists of a detailed plan with goals and success milestones. All this information would be enough to implement the proposal successfully. However, the fund requested for the proposal seems to be overpriced
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal consists of all the goals to be achieved and has a definition of success for 3,6 and 12 months. this information should be enough to audit and track the proposal but a complete detailed breakdown of funds needed would have also helped auditors.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposer of this project wants to create a community hub in caracas. The idea is really good as it introduces cardano to those who need it the most. As outlined by the proposer, the inflation rate is very high in the country, cardano can be a hedge against the inflation. I can say that the proposer has successfully identified the problem within the challenge. I think that this can add value to the cardano ecosystem. New users joining  the community can  help build the ecosystem up. The goal of this proposal aligns with the challenge. Furthermore, I think that the proposal could scale in future challenges if funded.
f6_assessments.q1: Although this proposal is a good idea, the missing information has diminished my confidence in its feasibility. The proposer claims to have been organizing crypto events since 2013, but there is no there is no evidence to back those claims. I think that the proposer should've added resources such as photos, videos or linkedin profiles. Furthermore, there is not much about the team needed to carry out the project. The budget breakdown is also really vague and should be broken down even more. There is also no mention for additional funding in case they need it. A comprehensible timetable is also missing in this proposal. I think that the proposal should better structure this proposal and add sections such as a roadmap, milestones, a detailed plan of execution (which is present) and some strong KPIs.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal is missing a roadmap and milestones. Metrics and KPIs that define success are present but, I think that the proposer should make them stronger in future funds. Besides these breaches, the problem has been described clearly and the solution is also present but it clearly needs to be improved. I think that I have a neutral note on the auditability of this proposal based on the information provided. Little improvements can give this proposal a good chance of being funded.
f6_assessments.reply:
Your feedback is much appreciated. 

To help address your concern about team information: 
- One of our team members, Antoine, has  been organizing this meetup in Toronto for 7 years: https://www.meetup.com/The-Bitcoin-Bay/

- We also have 3 Venezuelan members on the Cardano Hub Caracas team with additional event organizing experience (non crypto)
• Milangeli Romero (Venezuela)
• Antoine De Vuyst (Canada) 
• José Ramírez (Venezuela)
• Diana Aguilar (Venezuela)
You can come talk to us in our telegram group! t.me/Cardano_Caracas

Also see our comments on the previous review for a detailed budget breakdown. 

We're not sure why you said roadmap and milestones are missing as we have provided these.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal addresses a real world problem in a country where the local currency is too weak and the economy too poor to support development and growth. Cardano may provide an alternative way to empower people with more financial power. As the proposal suggests forming a community hub in Caracas will make Cardano adoption possible for people sitting in the next door. Although the goals seem to match the ones in the challenge I believe they are a little generic without a strong foundation. I agree that the proposal gives attention to the challenge, therefore I rate it with a score of 4.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposal does not provide much information for the team's experience other than just stating that that some Bitcoin meetings have been hosted in Venezuela. The team formation is completely missing and according to the provided meetup link it is only member in the team without any further evidence about his knowledge and experience. This comes in contradiction with the personal pronoun "We" used in the descriptions.
The requested funds are split into three main categories but there is no explanation how each amount derives. There is also no reasoning or rationale for airdropping $10000 worth of ADA.
The proposal suggests a basic implementation plan that looks realistic for the mentioned time frames. However it does give any details on how the Community Hub will attract and persuade people to hold ADA (and not Cardano as it mentions). Also, there is no information about the resources needed to execute the tasks.
There are not any risks identified to assess possible failures like not reaching the goal of 26 events in 1 year or not attracting people to the community.
Based on the above rationale I am neutral for a successful implementation. Therefore I rate it with a score of 3.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal provides a time horizon with some milestones and KPIs although not in great details. It also misses a description to measure the success, for example, how the ADA holders will be verified or how event participants will be counted and sustained in the local community. Any reference on the way to track and audit the progress of the project is missing too.
I disagree that the proposal can be audited in a sufficient manner so I rate it with a score of 2.
f6_assessments.reply:
We appreciate your valuable review. 

Please see our feedback to previous reviews for more information about our team! And for a more detailed budget breakdown and team info. 

To address your other concerns: 

- You have a great point about persuading people to hold ADA. We can propose encouraging community members to hold ADA as a hedge against inflation, as well as educating them on how and why to stake!

- For metrics we are planning to track how many community members stake ADA, and vote on Cardano Catalyst. We measure attendance using meetup.com, and manually at our meetups!

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is based in Caracas, Venezuela and addresses the challenge of educating local communities about Cardano. The project will onboard new members and open up opportunities to develop and avoid the high rates of inflation in this region. 

The project aligns with the challenge of scaling up Community Hubs through providing a localised option for onboarding community in Latin America. The project has potential to reach a global audience of spanish speakers using video platforms, however this particular idea is very much about localised in-person workshops. Perhaps that is something to consider for scaling up the idea in the future.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer is linked with a similar hub in Buenos Aires who were funded in F6, and it would appear this proposer has used the same timeline and project plan as the BA application that was previously funded. It might even be the same proposer? In assessing the success of the project it is unclear as to what skills and experience the proposer has, and indeed if they are specifically located in Caracas. There's a lot of empty links, videos that don't have content, calendars that have stopped events in 2020. It's hard to really say if this project is going to succeed. 

There is an existing github provided for the Caracas project, however it has very few (3) members. Again, to indicate some demand and increase confidence in providing funding it would be good to see some evidence base or substantiation of the proposer's skills in growing audiences and communities around these ideas. 

The budget is clear, however there is a questionable incentivisation of 10kUSD to the community, it's clear this would absolutely get people started with Cardano but without a captured group already in mind or a particular market this might not be the best way of encouraging participation in the Cardano community, rather it lends more to the investment model.
f6_assessments.q2:
The community can see events as they appear on the github provided as a way to audit the project progress. 


There is a missed opportunity in providing some form of recording or livestream to the community and growing a spanish speaking community around Cardano online as a result, this is something that was suggested to the other Buenos Aires project however it's unclear if they have taken that advice on board. 

There are KPI's and milestones, again these look to be the same as the Buenos Aires project milestones. There's a target number to grow participation. It's fairly achievable if you are literally giving away money for people to become a Cardano holder, however does that grow a community or does that disseminate money to people that aren't necessarily going to engage?
f6_assessments.reply:
To address your concerns

- We're not sure where you saw stopped events and empty links. Our meetup page is https://www.meetup.com/cardano-hub-caracas/. It started small but it is growing! Please remember we decided to start regardless of being funded or not. 

- We would also like to clarify that three of our current team members are indeed located in Caracas and have a detailed grasp of what's needed in order to reach our goals successfully.

- About airdrops, we have decided to reframe Airdrops as Community Contribution rewards. This should help draw passionate people and those willing to contribute to our community! We are definitely taking this feedback on board. 

- We did not provide a GitHub. Perhaps you're referring to our meetup page. We will do our best to provide recordings! 

- Please see our response to other reviews for budget breakdown and team info

solution: Créer un centre communautaire Cardano à Caracas. Organiser des ateliers éducatifs en espagnol, dirigés par des membres de la communauté locale.
experience:
Accueil de rencontres et d'ateliers sur le bitcoin depuis 2013.
Organisation de communautés crypto vénézuéliennes en ligne.
Organisation de rencontres Cardano à Toronto.
